awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Engineering point defect formation in UWBG-based optoelectronic devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Many applications such as optoelectronics and power electronics rely on the functionality of ultra wide bandgap materials. But to reach their full potential, it is necessary to understand and realize novel processes to enhance their performance, either electrically or optically. The proposed processing framework has the opportunity of revolutionizing these family of materials, thus providing for the achievement of properties that otherwise will not be attainable. This is in addition to providing a unifying conceptual approach consistent with modern computational efforts that bring about a non-Edisonian approach to the design of materials and processes dealing with this class of materials. This research will directly lead to applications that deal with the preservation and extension of natural resources by allowing for: the availability of clean potable water through disinfection by the use of ultraviolet light emitting diodes, and the detection of pollutants and other effluents. The novel concepts developed within this project can also be implemented in the educational and outreach efforts (some specifically targeted at minority students), especially integrating materials characterization and control schemes to applications dealing with the need for the development of materials for sustainability purposes. This program will provide the opportunity to educate Ph.D. students on the growth, characterization and device fabrication of these materials while participating on an established international collaborators network. Furthermore, integration of these ideas into design of new courses broadens the community of students and experts related to the topic, especially those dealing with computational methods. From this, graduate students and group members will be able to effectively discuss their research for fruitful collaborations while accelerating their professional growth.

Charged point defects in compound semiconductors strongly determine electronic and optical properties. The energy of formation of a point defect is a function of the process conditions and the Fermi energy. In ultra wide bandgap materials or insulators, the contribution of the Fermi energy to the formation energy of charged point defects is significant. For the practical case of doping for n- or p-type conductivity, the larger the energy gap, the higher the concentration of compensating point defects that is at equilibrium with the system. This is a fundamental problem of these materials that will be directly addressed with these capabilities. In this approach, we will extend the concept of the quasi-Fermi level in an effort to quantify the impact of external excitation in the formation energy of the point defect. Increasing the formation energy of unwanted point defect through external excitation during a growth experiment leads to a reduction in compensating point defects and higher device efficiencies. The research objective of this proposal is to test the hypothesis that the energy of formation of charged point defects could be manipulated by an external excitation in a steady-state condition during growth. Approaches include the introduction of above-bandgap illumination or e-beam irradiation as excitation sources. This process is referred to as Fermi level control of point defects. Three main research tasks are designed to test the hypothesis: (1) demonstration of Fermi level control of technologically important point defects during the growth of III-nitrides based UV LED structures, (2) optical and electrical study of point defects and their influence on the device performance, (3) extension to other wide bandgap systems and alternative Fermi level management processes to show universality of the process. This research will extend these capabilities to AlGaN for the engineered reduction of compensating and non-radiative defects in deep UV LEDs. It is expected that this process is generally applicable to a broad class of wide bandgap materials, in particular, several oxide systems.

por.por_cntn:
Many applications such as optoelectronics and power electronics rely on the functionality of wide and ultrawide bandgap semiconductors. But to reach their full potential, it is necessary to understand and realize novel processes to enhance their performance, either electrically or optically. This project helped bring about a new scientific paradigm in materials growth and processing through the control of crystal defects for the achievement of properties in these semiconductors that otherwise will not be attainable. The project led to the demonstration of effective control of electrical conductivity by controlling point defect formation in materials that were traditionally classified as insulators, extending their functionality. The results of this program will directly lead to semiconductor-based applications that deal with the preservation and extension of natural resources by allowing for: the availability of clean potable water through disinfection using ultraviolet light emitting diodes, and the detection of pollutants and other effluents. In addition, the performed research provides for a transformative and disruptive technology for power electronics revolutionizing energy switching and transmission, energy storage, and related applications in electrical motor drives and other power intensive applications.

The novel concepts developed within this project were also implemented in the educational and outreach efforts, especially integrating materials characterization and processing schemes to applications dealing with the need for the development of materials for sustainability purposes. Furthermore, integration of these ideas into design of new courses broadened the community of students and experts related to the semiconductor fields, where more than six students graduated with work related from this program.

Charged point defects in compound semiconductors strongly determine electronic and optical properties. The energy of formation of a point defect is a function of the process conditions and the Fermi energy. In wide and ultrawide bandgap materials or insulators, the contribution of the Fermi energy to the formation energy of charged point defects is significant. For the practical case of doping for n- or p-type conductivity, the larger the energy gap, the higher the concentration of compensating point defects that is at equilibrium with the system. This is a fundamental problem of these materials that was addressed with the semiconductor processing capabilities developed during this program. As part of the fundamental developments, we extended the concept of the quasi-Fermi level to quantify the impact of external excitation in the formation energy of the point defect. Increasing the formation energy of unwanted point defects through external excitation during a growth experiment leads to a reduction in compensating point defects and higher device efficiencies. The main research objective of this program was to demonstrate that the energy of formation of charged point defects could be manipulated by an external excitation in a steady-state condition during growth. Approaches include the introduction of above-bandgap illumination or e-beam irradiation as excitation sources. This process is referred to as Fermi level control of point defects. In addition, during the performance of the program, another point defect control scheme was developed: chemical potential control. Three main research tasks were pursued to develop and demonstrate these point defect control schemes: (1) demonstration of Fermi level control of technologically important point defects during the growth of III-nitrides based UV LED structures and power devices, (2) optical and electrical study of point defects and their influence on the device performance, (3) extension to other wide bandgap systems and alternative Fermi level management processes to show universality of the process. The research extended the capabilities from GaN to AlGaN and AlN for the engineered reduction of compensating and non-radiative defects in either deep UV LEDs or power devices. It was also demonstrated that this process is generally applicable to a broad class of wide bandgap materials, in particular, several oxide systems. 

The main project achievements are listed: (1) theoretical understanding and experimental validation of two different point defect control schemes, chemical potential control and defect quasi-Fermi level control; (2) implementation during metalorganic chemical vapor growth in n- and p-type GaN, AlGaN and AlN; (3) implementation during implantation recovery annealing in AlN; (4) identification of point defects throughout the whole compositional range in AlGaN by optical spectroscopy; (5) implementation during the development of UV LEDs emitting at 265 nm, increasing internal quantum efficiency and carrier concentration in injection layers; (6) demonstration in AlN Schottky diodes leading to the lowest ideality factor and eventual first demonstration of kA/cm2 current carrying capabilities; (7) implementation during growth of thick drift layers for GaN junction barrier Schottky diodes. Other research groups have reported implementation of these schemes in different material system, suggesting the fast adoption of these point defect control schemes by the broad materials science community. The technology developed was implemented in UV optoelectronic devices to record breaking III-nitrides power devices ranging in bandgap from GaN to AlN.
